newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine, Deere and Co sign combine deal.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine, Deere and Co sign combine deal.

text.p: U.S. farm equipment manufacturer Deere and Company signed a deal on Tuesday to provide parts to build 6,400 combine harvesters in the next five years at a southern Ukrainian tractor factory, company officials said.

"John Deere will provide components, training and technical support," Deere's Chairman Hans Becherer said at a news conference. "We will provide assistance in the final manufacture of combines at Kherson."

He added talks would be held on formation of a joint venture between the Khersonsky Traktorny Zavod KTZ and John Deere, which last year sealed a $187 million deal to provide 1,049 combines to Ukraine under U.S. guarantees.
Ukraine's farms, almost six years after independence from the Soviet Union, are suffering from severe shortages of modern machinery, as well as money and fuel.
Becherer said the value of the deal, which called for building 300 combines for the 1998 harvest season, would be determined by success in building and selling the equipment.
"The total value will depend on the development of local content," he said, adding exports of combines might take place in the "long term future".
Agriculture Minister Mykhailo Zubets said combines would be sold to cash-strapped farms under lease agreements.
"We have to furnish the agriculture sector with modern technology," he said. "This will also allow us to renew this factory which in recent times has not been working."
Becherer said Deere was also discussing forming a joint venture with Pivdenmash in the eastern industrial city of Dnipropetrovsk.

A spokesman from Pivdenmash said the company, which builds missiles, buses and appliances and which has been courted by several farm machinery builders including Case Europe, would decide on a joint venture partner this month.
